item.title: How Karl’s career was turned upside down - The Advertiser
item.description:
How Karl’s career was turned upside down  The Advertiser

But somehow, Nine’s golden boy has managed to overcome the intense public scrutiny and speculation about his future in TV with the network to get to the altar. Earlier this year, Nine’s CEO Hugh Marks even admitted that Karl’s private relationship drama had taken its toll. In September, Marks told The Australian: “No doubt the constant publicity surrounding issues with his personal life have had an impact on Karl, his colleagues and on the show. We can’t hide from that. And as a result we know there’s a lot of hard work to be done to win back the audience.” MORE: James Packer’s last-minute ...

Related: Today stars Sylvia and Peter arrive in Mexico for Karl’s wedding Related: Karl and Jasmine spotted heading off to Mexico for wedding Related: Weird reality TV link to Karl and Jasmine’s wedding Yarbrough will get ready for the big day with her high sc...

item.title: Packer pulls out of Stefanovic’s wedding - The Advertiser
item.description:
Packer pulls out of Stefanovic’s wedding  The Advertiser

The billionaire has reportedly pulled out of his close mate’s wedding at the last minute in order to attend his mother’s 80th birthday, according to The Daily Telegraph. RELATED: Here’s what we know about Karl and Jasmine’s OTT wedding Packer, 51, was long thought to be one of the celebrity guests flying in for the December 8 nuptials in Mexico. Ros Packer, who was married to media mogul Kerry Packer for 42 years before his death in 2005, is believed to have flown to Argentina to meet her son and continue her birthday celebrations in South America. In November, it was widely reported that t...

item.title: Macquarie Media shares jump - The Australian
item.description:
Macquarie Media shares jump  The Australian

Macquarie Media shares jumped more than 12 per cent yesterday after Nine Entertainment confirmed it was looking to mop up the shareholding of the radio company, home of 2GB’s top radio stars Alan Jones and Ray Hadley. Nine will own a 54.5 per cent stake in ASX-listed Macquarie Media after its $4 billion merger with Fairfax Media wraps up on Friday but that leaves the remaining 45.5 per cent up for grabs. Top advertising boss John Singleton is Macquarie Media’s second biggest shareholder with 32 per cent. The remaining balance is owned by minority shareholders, which include Wilson Asset Man...

item.title: Massive shake-up at Today show - The Advertiser
item.description:
Massive shake-up at Today show  The Advertiser

In an email to staff today, Channel 9 news director Darren Wick confirmed Calvert would leave the embattled breakfast program after five years at the helm. “From personal experience, I know there is no more challenging role in news and current affairs than the daily breakfast battle between Today and Sunrise. It’s a national ratings race where audience loyalty fluctuates from city to city, and often suburb to suburb,” Mr Wick wrote. “And there is no program on Australian television that is analysed, revised and criticised as much as Today. The hours are exhausting, the competition is intens...

item.title: Everything we know about Karl’s OTT wedding - The Advertiser
item.description:
Everything we know about Karl’s OTT wedding  The Advertiser

The couple, who became engaged in January after a whirlwind 11-month romance, have arrived in Los Angeles ahead of their Mexican nuptials this weekend. THE VENUE Stefanovic and Yarbrough will tie the knot at the luxurious One & Only Palmilla Resort in San Jose del Cabo on Saturday, December 8. The resort is a favourite of celebrities such as Cameron Diaz and Jennifer Aniston and was also where The Hills’ Heidi Montag and Spencer Pratt eloped in 2008. Today host Stefanovic and shoe designer Yarbrough are expected to exchange vows in the resort’s white chapel and have reportedly shelled out t...

item.title: Karl Stefanovic blows up at Princess Di's former Butler - The Australian
item.description:

Karl Stefanovic blows up at Princess Di's former Butler, Paul Burrell after he said Kate Middleton didn't have the X Factor. Courtesy: The TODAY Show/Channel Nine

item.title: This Time Next Year pulls its lowest audience yet with 764,000 - mUmBRELLA*
item.description:
This Time Next Year pulls its lowest audience yet with 764,000  mUmBRELLA*

Karl Stefanovic’s This Time Next Year, airing on Nine at 8.40pm, pulled its lowest audience to date with 764,000 metro viewers. Despite having its lowest audience number, the program still managed to top its timeslot and beat Ten’s 668,000 for Have You Been Paying Attention. According to OzTAM’s overnight preliminary metro date Seven’s Diana, 7 Days – which aired at 8.45pm – managed an audience of 467,000, finishing 19th on the ratings ladder. Nine’s renovation series The Block topped the ratings leaderboard as 1.101m metro viewers tuned in to watch. The Block, which aired at 7.30pm, was th...

item.title: Viewers cool on Hell’s Kitchen as The Block and Survivor win Monday prime time - mUmBRELLA*
item.description:
Viewers cool on Hell’s Kitchen as The Block and Survivor win Monday prime time  mUmBRELLA*

The second episode of Seven’s new cooking show Hell’s Kitchen failed to beat Nine or Ten’s rival reality shows when they went head to head at prime time last night. While the show premiered with 817,000 metro viewers on Sunday, last night’s audience averaged 615,000 metro viewers, behind Nine’s The Block and Ten’s Australian Survivor, which had metro audiences of 1.093m and 637,000 respectively. Last night the celebrities were taken to a farm Hell’s Kitchen also failed to get traction in the key advertising demographics – 16-39s, 18-49s, and 25-54s – last night, with Nine’s The Block toppin...

item.title: ABC’s line-up of 7.30, Australian Story and Four Corners beats Hell’s Kitchen and Australian Survivor - mUmBRELLA*
item.description:
ABC’s line-up of 7.30, Australian Story and Four Corners beats Hell’s Kitchen and Australian Survivor  mUmBRELLA*

The national broadcaster’s news and current affairs line-up last night trumped Seven’s struggling reality franchise Hell’s Kitchen and Ten’s Australian Survivor. Last night Four Corners investigated Australia’s ‘housing bubble’ It was also a strong showing for Nine – which easily won the night with a 23.2% audience share – with The Block, Nine News, A Current Affair and Karl Stefanovic’s This Time Next Year all appearing in the top 10 programs list. The most-watched program on Monday evening was The Block with 1.139m metro viewers, according to OzTAM’s overnight preliminary metro ratings, h...

item.title: To halal and back: a year on - The Australian
item.description:
To halal and back: a year on  The Australian

First up tonight, Australian Story explores the life and times of Dastyari — also detailed in his new memoir One Halal of a Story, published today — who moved to Australia from Iran at the age of four and joined the Labor Party at 16, before rapidly moving through the ranks. More recently he was found to have broken Labor Party donation rules by allowing Chinese donors to pay bills on his behalf; later, it was revealed he had contradicted ALP policy on the South China Sea at a press conference he had given with a major Chinese donor, precipitating his resignation from the frontbench. He tel...

item.title: Worner changes tune on TV - The Australian
item.description:
Worner changes tune on TV  The Australian

Hi-tech harassing It was a big splash in the weekend editions of The Sydney Morning Herald and The Age. “Blow jobs for investment: sexual harassment claims spiral in the tech industry,” ran the online headline for an article by Cara Waters, Fairfax’s small business editor. The explosive article told the story of entrepreneur Atlanta Daniel, who met with a prospective business backer assisting her in a start-up technology venture and was asked to give him a blow job. The graphic nature of the article attracted complaints, from Daniel herself, who said pictures of her and graphic tweets were ...

item.title: Government slammed over same sex postal vote - The Advertiser
item.description:
Government slammed over same sex postal vote  The Advertiser

The government has been slammed over the idea to hold a same sex postal vote in a Sarrah Le Marquand article in News Corp papers. Karl Stefanovic gives his verdict on the controversial decision. Courtesy: Today Show

item.title: Launch of This Time Next Year and The Block help Nine to a weekly ratings win - mUmBRELLA*
item.description:
Launch of This Time Next Year and The Block help Nine to a weekly ratings win  mUmBRELLA*

The two most-watched programs of the ratings week may have been on Seven – with Sunday Night and Seven News on Sunday pulling 1.334m and 1.303m respectively – but the strong launches of both The Block and Karl Stefanovic’s This Time Next Year, mean Nine won week 31 with a 21.2% audience share, compared to Seven’s 20.5%. Last Sunday’s This Time Next Year was the most-watched entertainment program of the week ABC and Ten tied for the week with 11.4% each, and SBS was in fifth place with a 4.7% share. The premiere of This Time Next Year placed third for the week thanks to an audience of 1.280m...

item.title: Fashion’s A-listers out in force for David Jones - The Advertiser
item.description:
Fashion’s A-listers out in force for David Jones  The Advertiser

Sydney’s A list were out in force for the annual event but they weren’t all well behaved. Taking centre stage was international models Shanina Shaik and Bridget Malcolm alongside the store’s ambassadors Jesinta Franklin and Jess Gomes. Franklin revealed she rushed to the salon after she received a call from DJs bosses last week, asking her to go a little blonder. She said it took over 16 hours to bleach her locks blond just for the show. “It’s taken a long time. I did two six hours sessions last week and another four hours on Saturday,” Franklin said. The new Bachelor Matty J was in a serio...

item.title: Where it all went wrong for Karl - The Advertiser
item.description:
Where it all went wrong for Karl  The Advertiser

When he infamously showed up to work still drunk the morning after the Logie Awards in 2009, slurring and giggling his way through hours of live television, viewers lapped it up. As the co-host of Channel 9’s Today show, he was both the daggy dad, self-deprecating and entertaining, as well as a steady hand that lounge rooms turned to in a crisis. With the click of his fingers, Stefanovic could expertly swap hats from family friendly star, fronting everything from Carol’s By Candlelight to This Time Next Year, to hard-nosed newshound on the frontline of major breaking events at home and arou...

item.title: Karl breaks silence after firing reports - The Advertiser
item.description:
Karl breaks silence after firing reports  The Advertiser

Speculation has reached fever pitch that the once bankable television star has become toxic and the tide of unease from viewers cannot be turned. A damning report in The Sunday Telegraph quotes senior sources at the network saying that Stefanovic will be told this week that he won’t return to Today in the new year. The TV star broke his silence following the report by posting a photo to Instagram on Sunday night of himself holding a beer and smiling with fiancee Jasmine Yarbrough, brother Peter and friend Chris Waller. “I’m incredibly grateful for the family and friends I have in this world...

item.title: Nine’s Today Show falls below 200,000 metro viewers - mUmBRELLA*
item.description:
Nine’s Today Show falls below 200,000 metro viewers  mUmBRELLA*

Nine’s breakfast program Today managed just 199,000 metro viewers on Tuesday night, despite airing across all markets. According to OzTAM’s overnight preliminary metro ratings, the Today Show saw 320,000 viewers tune in across the nation, leaving the show 34th on the ratings ladder for Tuesday. Nine’s Today Show yesterday fell below 200,00 viewers Meanwhile, Seven’s rival breakfast program Sunrise averaged 268,000 metro viewers and 445,000 nationally. In November last year, The Today Show saw a shakeup of its co-hosts when Georgie Gardner replaced long-standing co-host Lisa Wilkinson, who d...

item.title: ‘Kick her out’: Hanson lashes anthem girl - The Advertiser
item.description:
‘Kick her out’: Hanson lashes anthem girl  The Advertiser

Harper Nielsen, a student at Kenmore South State School in Brisbane, decided to protest against Advance Australia Fair, saying it was not inclusive of indigenous Australians. The Courier-Mailnewspaper broke the story about the Year 4 student and how the school told her she had to stand or leave the building. When she refused to do either, the school handed the Year 4 student a lunchtime detention for “blatant disrespect”. She was then told that she could not leave the office until she had signed a written apology and that she could be suspended. The issue has this morning sparked a bitter d...

item.title: How TV will change once Nine takes over Fairfax Media - ABC News
item.description:
How TV will change once Nine takes over Fairfax Media  ABC News

Karl Stefanovic as a radio jock. Alan Jones on Channel Nine. And some of the country's best investigative reporters switching their exposes from corrupt politicians to shonky plumbers. They're some of the predictions of how a merger of Nine and Fairfax Media could change Australia's media landscape in the months and years ahead. Marketing lecturer David Waller from the University of Technology, Sydney, says the merger would open up opportunities for cross promotion between television programs and Fairfax assets, such as Nine's The Block and the real estate website Domain. It's no secret the...

item.title: Lisa’s surprise return to Nine - The Advertiser
item.description:
Lisa’s surprise return to Nine  The Advertiser

Wilkinson departed Nine for rival network Ten in October last year — but just seven weeks later, when last night’s episode was filmed in December 2017, she was back on her former employer’s turf to support her son. Interestingly, while Louis’ two siblings, Billi and Jake, and father, Peter FitzSimons, ran alongside the course during his run, Lisa stayed in the bleachers with the rest of the audience. The Project co-host could be seen grinning from ear to ear and recording her son’s efforts with her phone. “Although I am my parents’ son, I am my own man, and I’m here to prove that today,” th...

item.title: Hughesy’s searing Stefanovic roast - The Advertiser
item.description:
Hughesy’s searing Stefanovic roast  The Advertiser

“Be careful Stefanovics,” Hughes said about taking an Uber after the awards event. “Whether it’s a cab or an Uber mate, leave a tip,” he told Karl from the stage. “Then they don’t have to make any extra money selling the story to New Idea.” MORE: 60 Minutes gets shock Logie gong PICTURE SPECIAL: Best and worst dressed at the Logies Hughes continued: “If you don’t know the story … Karl was on loudspeaker in an Uber … you shouldn’t have been bitching about your work colleagues.” To recap, Peter Stefanovic rang Karl from an Uber, and the brothers shared a few unkind words about their Nine work...

item.title: Fresh faces in the running for 2018 Gold Logie - ABC News
item.description:
Fresh faces in the running for 2018 Gold Logie  ABC News

The 2018 Gold Logie will be awarded to a first-time winner, with the list of nominations for the award featuring a batch of new faces. The nominations for the July 1 awards were announced on Sunday at The Star on the Gold Coast, which will host Australian television's biggest awards night for the first time. A Current Affair host Tracy Grimshaw join's Ten Network's Amanda Keller and Grant Denyer, actors Jessica Marais and Rodger Corser, and lifestyle presenter Andrew Winter in the race for the Gold. Grimshaw, Keller, Denyer and Winter have also been nominated for most popular presenter, alo...

item.title: Surprising snubs in Logies noms - The Advertiser
item.description:
Surprising snubs in Logies noms  The Advertiser

Star recruit Lisa Wilkinson and Waleed Aly — who won the Most Popular Presenter award last year — have both been left out of the running for the 2018 awards which will be held on the Gold Coast on July 1. This year’s Gold Logie nominees are: The Living Room’s Amanda Keller, actors Jessica Marais and Rodger Corser, A Current Affair host Tracey Grimshaw, Family Feud’s Grant Denyer and Love It Or List It presenter Andrew Winter. Winter’s inclusion marks the first time a Foxtel presenter has been nominated in that category. The Project and its hosts have long been Logies favourites. Carrie Bick...

item.title: Seven and Nine go ad-free for Royal Wedding - mUmBRELLA*
item.description:
Seven and Nine go ad-free for Royal Wedding  mUmBRELLA*

Australia’s two major commercial television networks will drop advertising for the duration of tonight’s Royal Wedding ceremony . Both Nine and Seven are ditching their normal schedules to cover the marriage of Prince Harry and Meghan Markle. Nine will feature the BBC’s coverage while Seven will turn to ITV’s Tim Ewart. The wedding service will also be aired on ABC and SBS. Nine and Seven’s coverage will kick off at 7pm eastern, with ABC and SBS’s broadcasts starting half an hour later. The first couple of hours will focus on coverage of guests arriving at the service in Windsor, with the R...

item.title: Raggy ‘flattered’ by Today host speculation - The Advertiser
item.description:
Raggy ‘flattered’ by Today host speculation  The Advertiser

Ragless is the network’s preferred choice to fill breakfast TV’s top job should Stefanovic be moved on, according to reports. A poll on advertiser.com.au showed 78 per cent of more than 600 voters backed Ragless taking the job. But local Nine insiders said Ragless, who was out of range in the Flinders Ranges on Sunday, isn’t going anywhere yet. “Raggy” would be a surprise choice to replace Stefanovic, whose leaked Uber conversation with brother Peter about co-host Georgie Gardner angered Gardner and Nine bosses. In contrast, executives were reportedly impressed with Ragless’s “natural, ever...

item.title: Big pay-off in Jo’s risky move - The Advertiser
item.description:
Big pay-off in Jo’s risky move  The Advertiser

In an unscripted moment of on-air candour, Griggs — the affable, easygoing host of family-friendly Better Homes & Gardens — proved she’s not just a relatable mum-of-two who froths about DIY renos and can talk sport. She’s bold, opinionated and fearless. In two minutes, she gave a gutsier and more authentic moment than anything we’ve seen all year on any breakfast television show. The 44-year-old’s lashing on Sunday night was gobsmacking in the best possible way. While her co-host Basil Zempilas described the lacklustre and heavily panned Closing Ceremony as “disappointing”, it was Griggs wh...

item.title: The curious case of the Stefanovic brothers and the non-existent Uber tapes - mUmBRELLA*
item.description:
The curious case of the Stefanovic brothers and the non-existent Uber tapes  mUmBRELLA*

It’s been about a week since rumours first emerged of the existence of the “Secret Stefanovic Tapes”, an illicit recording of Karl and Peter Stefanovic venting about Channel Nine colleagues. As the mysterious tapes were allegedly shopped around by an Uber driver, (though it’s now claimed they never existed) speculation about their contents was rife. Given the hype, you could be forgiven for thinking the impact for Australian morning television would be akin to the impact of the Watergate tapes for American politics. But when the details of the conversation were finally revealed by New Idea ...

item.title: Nine’s Stefanovic brothers offer ‘sincerest apologies’ for alleged Uber rant about colleagues - mUmBRELLA*
item.description:
Nine’s Stefanovic brothers offer ‘sincerest apologies’ for alleged Uber rant about colleagues  mUmBRELLA*

Channel Nine hosts and brothers Peter and Karl Stefanovic have offered their “sincerest apologies” for a conversation an Uber driver allegedly overheard last week. According to an article published in The Daily Telegraph, the brothers were allegedly overheard talking negatively about their co-workers Georgie Gardner, Mark Burrows and Richard Wilkins during a phone conversation which Peter Stefanovic put on speaker. Stefanovic and co-host Gardner News outlets are speculating the conversation will appear in Seven West Media-owned New Idea this week, however the publication is claiming the art...

item.title: The Stefanovic story: Where are Uber and New Idea’s PR crises? - mUmBRELLA*
item.description:
The Stefanovic story: Where are Uber and New Idea’s PR crises?  mUmBRELLA*

When I contemplated penning an article on the Stefanovic/Uber PR disaster, I rubbed my hands in glee at seeing commentators having a PR pop at the world’s biggest kitty pimps and executive men-on-the-make. By which I mean Uber, not the broadcast brothers. I imagined critics having a go at Uber’s alleged culture of brazen corporate opportunism, misguided staff and its patchy PR responses in managing such company mis-steps. Personally, I found it sinister that an Uber driver may have recorded private conversations of their passengers to seek reward for passing on grubby digital files. Wasn’t ...

item.title: Georgie Gardner’s first outing on Today pulls 256,000 metro viewers - mUmBRELLA*
item.description:
Georgie Gardner’s first outing on Today pulls 256,000 metro viewers  mUmBRELLA*

Georgie Gardner’s first episode as co-host of Nine’s Today Show alongside Karl Stefanovic pulled 256,000 viewers across the five capital cities, behind rival Sunrise’s 281,000, according to OzTAM’s overnight preliminary metro ratings. Gardner debuted as co-host yesterday Today, however, beat Seven’s Sunrise in Sydney (79,000 viewers compared to 66,000) and Melbourne (66,000 compared to 63,000) and across the key advertising demographics of 16-39s, 18-49s and 25-54s. Lisa Wilkinson abruptly left Nine and Today in October last year following a breakdown in contract negotiations. Less than an ...

item.title: BBC Breakfast calls out Nine’s Today Show for copycat ad - mUmBRELLA*
item.description:
BBC Breakfast calls out Nine’s Today Show for copycat ad  mUmBRELLA*

The BBC has called out Nine on Twitter for the similarities between its Today Show promo and one created by the UK broadcaster in 2016. In a video posted to its Twitter page, the BBC notes comparisons between the two ads. We thought this looked familiar!!! pic.twitter.com/tiZuDaCQVE — BBC Breakfast (@BBCBreakfast) January 19, 2018 The uncannily similar promos both feature a woman turning on her TV, followed by her son – who in both instances is called Jack – burning his toast. The ads both feature the show’s presenters speaking to the family through the TV, and include a mention of how incr...

item.title: Nine reveals Allison Langdon and Peter Stefanovic as new hosts of Weekend Today - mUmBRELLA*
item.description:
Nine reveals Allison Langdon and Peter Stefanovic as new hosts of Weekend Today  mUmBRELLA*

Nine has announced a brand new line up for its Weekend Today show, with 60 Minutes reporters Allison Langdon and Peter Stefanovic to take the helm as co-hosts. Last year, Weekend Today was run by co-hosts Tom Steinfort and Deborah Knight. Knight announced her departure from Weekend Today in December while Tom Steinfort revealed he was leaving the show two days ago, to take up a full time role with 60 Minutes. Steinfort joined Weekend Today a year ago, replacing Stefanovic who moved to 60 Minutes. According to Nine, Langdon will continue in her role on 60 Minutes while Stefanovic will join t...

item.title: Of TV… and light sabers - mUmBRELLA*
item.description:
Of TV… and light sabers  mUmBRELLA*

While Dr Mumbo loves many things about the ABC, it’s hard to pick any aspect of the broadcaster which tops last night’s effort by the Screen Time show. Imagine the year’s biggest TV moments… but with the addition of lightsabers. Mind you, Dr Mumbo does wonder if the moment when Karl Stefanovic slices Lisa Wilkinson’s head off perhaps goes just a tad too far… The post Of TV… and light sabers appeared first on Mumbrella.
